titleStmt.title: Minutes of Historical Advisory Committee Meeting, August 1993
HAC Meeting Minutes, 1993

div.head: ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON HISTORICAL DIPLOMATIC DOCUMENTATION AUGUST 5, 1993

item.p: John R. Hancock, Chief, Information Security Division
Jeanne Schauble, Director, Records Declassification Division
David A. Langbart, Archivist, Records Appraisal and Disposition Division
J. Kenneth McDonald, Chief Historian, CIA
Page Putnam Miller, Director, National Coordinating Committee for Promotion of History

row.cell: Report by the Historian on the Status of the Foreign Relations series, and the New Declassification Unit
Subcommittee Report on the Department’s 30-Year Old and Older Records
John R. Hancock, Report on Presidential Review Directive (PRD-29)
Subcommittee Report on State Access to DoD Files
J. Kenneth McDonald, Report on CIA Publication and Declassification Activities
Subcommittee Report on the New Editorial Policy and Practices (1964-68, Vol. XI, Arms Control)
Comments on the Working Group’s Action Plan for Opening the Department’s Records
Prepared by Committee Member Anna K. Nelson August 6, 1993 in response to Committee’s discussion on the Working Group’s Action Plan

div.p: Committee Chairman Warren Kimball called the meeting to order at 9:08 a.m. and asked for approval of the draft minutes. Department Historian and Executive Secretary of the Committee William Z. Slany said he had classified correspondence bearing on the draft minutes which he would bring to the closed session in the afternoon. Kimball said the correspondence was from a participant at the last meeting who thought a portion of the minutes should be classified. He stated that he objected to having any of the minutes classified, although he did not object to adding notes to the minutes to enable participants to clarify their statements. Director of Historical Documents Review Joe H. Chaddic noted that he had not seen the draft minutes.

Kimball stated that Deputy Assistant Secretary Bennett Freeman would be joining the committee for lunch, and that he planned to adjourn at 11:45 a.m. so that the committee could go over topics they would discuss at lunch.

Slany presented the Historian’s report. He stated that the series is on schedule in terms of publishing and accelerating publication to a 30-year line by 1996. HO will publish 14 volumes this year and nearly 20 next year. HO is spending all the funds available to it for publication in this fiscal year.

He stated that a major achievement has been the creation of a declassification unit within HO to handle liaison with other agencies and foreign governments in the declassification process. Four positions for the new division have been posted; in the meantime, David Herschler and Jeff Soukup have been detailed. Nelson asked whether the positions for the new division represented a diversion of resources from the compilation of the series. Slany said they did not; three positions had come from the A Bureau. On the subject of declassification, he noted that the Soviet volume for 1961-1963 had gone through the clearance process with no material removed--an historic first.

Slany reported that there had been a number of staff changes since the last meeting. Two historians have left or are about to leave; Nina J. Noring has retired and Taylor Fain is leaving to pursue an advanced degree. A senior technical editor, Althea Robinson, retired, and the Deputy Historian’s secretary moved to another office. PA has agreed to fill all vacancies. It is not clear how many historian positions can be filled from outside the Department, although Assistant Secretary Donilon supports doing so. Kimball noted that he had written to Donilon reiterating the committee’s concern about HO
staffing and urging that HO needed to be able to recruit from outside the Department. Slany stated that the new chief of the Asia and Americas Division is Edward C. Keefer, and the new head of the Middle East, South Asia, and Africa Division is Harriet D. Schwar. David Humphrey has arrived from the Johnson Library to fill a previous vacancy.

On the subject of access, Slany stated that HO is progressing in discussions with Harry Middleton concerning the Johnson tapes. He noted that Ken McDonald would be available later to discuss HO access to CIA materials. He stated that HO is trying to work out an access arrangement with NSA. HO has requested access to earlier material as well as material of the 1964-1968 period. He thought HO would have an MOU with the JCS by the next Advisory Committee meeting.

Bradford Perkins questioned the declassification backlog at some referral agencies, noting that some of the 1961-1963 volumes were behind schedule as well as some earlier volumes which have been in clearance for years. Slany thought HO’s assumption of responsibility for liaison with other agencies would speed up the process. He observed that the new division had only recently begun to address the long-standing problems to which Perkins had referred. He noted that Donilon had agreed to weigh in with other agencies if necessary. Perkins asked about the time required between final clearance of a volume and its publication. He asked if that was due to GPO. Rita Baker stated that it was partly due to GPO and partly to the workload of the HO technical editors.

Kimball asked whether the problem concerning physical aspects of security which Slany had mentioned at the last meeting was interfering with HO’s work. General Editor Glenn W. LaFantasie said it was a relatively minor problem. HO is awaiting DS action on an arrangement which would simplify procedures. Kimball stated that HO should let the committee know if the problem interfered with work on the series.

Has any progress been made in getting an MOU with the Defense Department, asked Kimball? Anna Nelson said Brian Kinney, Chief of the Declassification and Historical Research Branch at Defense, had met with the subcommittee on HO access to DOD records the day before and had stated that Defense would agree to an MOU although they still thought it was unnecessary.

Kimball asked whether conflict between HO researchers and private researchers at presidential libraries was a problem. He noted that John Fawcett had mentioned this at the last
meeting as a hypothetical problem. LaFantasie said HO had a detailed schedule of presidential library visits. The Johnson Library was informed well in advance of HO research trips. David Humphrey stated that this had not been a problem at the library.
In a question raised by Kimball about the disposition of Advisory Committee records, Slany stated that HO would send them to NARA after an appropriate period of time.

Kimball asked if HO was keeping presidential libraries informed of declassification decisions. Slany stated that HO was developing a database that it would share with presidential libraries. Nelson asked about declassification of classified material in private collections such as the Harriman Papers at the Library of Congress. There was agreement that efforts should be made to keep the curators of such collections informed about declassification of those materials.

The Tibet issue was raised by Kimball, and LaFantasie replied that HO has not received a reply from the China desk or from CIA. Jeanne Pryor stated that a new country director had just taken over, and that the Foreign Service officer who met with the subcommittee at the last meeting was planning to discuss it with him. She expected to have a memorandum from the desk by the end of August.

The subject of the MOU between HO and HDR concerning the transfer of the coordination of the FRUS declassification process from HDR to HO was raised by Kimball. Perkins questioned why HO should clear with HDR its referrals of documents to foreign governments for clearance. It was pointed out that the Department might make a determination either to withhold or release a document; in either case, it should not be referred to a foreign government. LaFantasie explained that HO envisioned that referrals to other agencies and foreign governments would occur at the same time the manuscript was sent to HDR; thus HO would be making referrals before receiving the results of HDR’s review. For this reason, it was necessary to clear the referrals with HDR, which would clear with the regional Bureaus.

Attention was directed to the draft guidance on determination of equities. In the section on DOD equity, Kimball thought provision assigning DOD equity to all documents with information on military plans and operations was too vague. He thought a discussion between the President and the Secretary of State, with no Defense representative present, concerning the possible use of force should not have to be sent to DOD for clearance. LaFantasie pointed out that “hypothetical plans and operations contained in a non-Defense document without Defense input” were specifically exempted.

Nelson asked whether the draft guidance represented any change. She thought it was important that in assuming this new responsibility, HO should not bend over backwards and interpret other-agency equities too broadly. She asked about the assignment of CIA equity to every document identifying CIA personnel, even as non-speaking participants in a meeting. If Richard Bissell, whose role in the CIA is well-known, attended a meeting without saying anything, does the CIA have equity and can it excise Bissell’s name? LaFantasie noted that it was important to distinguish between the question of equities and questions of declassification.

Expressing concern about the definition of foreign government equity and foreign government information (FGI), Kimball thought the draft guidance was too broad and vague on this point. He argued that U.S. memoranda of conversation with foreign officials should not be withheld because of FGI and that there should not be any foreign government equity in such documents. Nelson noted that FGI had never been an issue until the promulgation of Executive order 12065 during the Carter administration. There was general discussion of the problem of FGI in U.S. documents. David Patterson stated that only documents with high-level foreign involvement required referral under the guidance. Chaddic stated that HDR’s treatment of FGI depended on the substance of the discussion, but Jeanne Pryor pointed out that FRUS documents were by definition substantive. Nelson expressed concern about the last paragraph of the section on NSC equities. Kimball stated that the committee was not entirely happy with the draft guidance, especially the section on foreign government equity, and proposed that a subcommittee should look further into the subject. The committee was in general agreement with this.

The report of the subcommittee on the Department’s 30-year-old records was presented by Warren Kimball. Kimball, Arnold Taylor, and Perkins, substituting for Emily Rosenberg, visited the National Records Center in Suitland the previous day to observe the implementation of the Department’s plan to speed up declassification. Kimball observed the work of the NARA declassifiers on pre-1960 records; Perkins and Taylor looked at the work of HDR declassifiers on 1960-1963 records. To some: extent, their comments reflected this division of labor.

Kimball stated that all three were concerned that neither the NARA nor the HDR declassifiers seemed to understand the Privacy Act. One of the tasks of the declassifiers is to determine when documents are protected by the Privacy Act; documents marked “P” for Privacy Act are closed for 100 years. He stated that some documents concerning foreign nationals have
been marked “P”, although the Privacy Act protects only U.S. citizens. He thought some documents marked “P” had been so marked because they contained information that might be embarrassing; this is not a valid reason for keeping documents closed.

Perkins stated that he had seen biographical materials on foreign leaders which were marked for CIA review, even though they were not on CIA letterhead and contained no references to sources and methods. William Hamilton stated that the CIA had responsibility for all government-produced bios (except those prepared by FSO’s) under an inter-agency agreement of some ten years ago. Kimball asked if there were other such “secret agreements.” Chaddic and Hamilton thought not. Perkins thought the bios would be useful to scholars although not to FRUS. There was general agreement that this issue should be explored.

Kimball was concerned about withdrawal sheets in the NARA records indicating that some documents had been returned to INR. Chaddic stated that this was a question of compartmentalized information. Some documents in the central files and lot files are not supposed to be there. He stated that NARA is negotiating with INR concerning the transfer of INR records to NARA. In order to do this, INR must be convinced that NARA will take all necessary precautions to safeguard the documents for which INR has responsibility. David Langbart of NARA stated that the documents have not been returned to INR but remain in NARA custody in an appropriate storage area. When and if they are declassified, they will be returned to the files. He thought the integrity of the files would be preserved if the agreed procedures are followed.
The committee recessed for a coffee break at 10:45 a.m.

After a coffee break, the Historical Advisory Committee reconvened at 11:05 a.m. to receive a briefing from John Hancock, Chief of the Information Security Division, Bureau of Diplomatic Security, Department of State, on Presidential Review Directive (PRD-29). Hancock explained that he, as the State Department representative on the PRD-29 task force, would give an account of the origins of the task force, how it was organized, and its work to date. At the first meeting of the task force, he was assigned to chair a committee on duration, one of seven committees, to study the question of classification duration of government records. PRD-29 was issued in early April 1993. Its purpose was to revisit and
redraft Executive Order 12356 to deal with classified material in the post-Cold War era. Questions for study would include classifying only truly sensitive material and to ask, among other things, whether existing classification categories and controls were still needed.

President Clinton appointed Steve Garfinckle, Director of the Information Security Oversight Office (ISOO), as chair of the PRD Task Force. Garfinckle put together a list of 21 government agencies and offices that were to comprise the task force. The task force held its first meeting in mid-May. The 20-30 people represented were broken into committees to look at specific parts of the existing executive order. Garfinckle himself raised the above questions for study in his instructions to the task force. The seven committees were classification standards, excessive classification, duration, access, declassification, oversight, and safeguards. Hancock repeated that he was assigned to the duration committee, along with representatives of the Federal Emergency Relief Agency, Navy, and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Jim Sandlin of DS/PRD is the alternate State representative to the task force. Each committee was to proceed independently.

For the committee on duration, phase 1 involved the development of a definition of the committee’s scope and mission. Phase 2 dealt with data gathering both outside and inside the government arena. The members gathered a lot of literature. They also conducted preliminary interviews with the National Coordinating Committee for the Promotion of History (Page Miller), American Civil Liberties Union (Keith Martin), National Security Archives (Tom Blanton), American Federation of Scientists, National Security Studies, and industry representatives. They also talked to former Director of Central Intelligence Bob Gates and government representatives at the Central Intelligence Agency. Hancock regretted that he had not earlier talked to the Historical Advisory Committee (HAC). He thought the HAC had already completed its work based on the initial timetable established, and added that it was not too late for the Committee to have some input in the process. The duration committee specifically considered whether to have an automatic declassification date for some kinds of documents or continue the line-by-line review.

July 2 was the target date for committees to submit recommendations to Garfinckle. In July, ISOO took the seven committee recommendations and developed a new executive order. It was not an easy task to mesh the ideas of all the committees, but a draft was completed by July 31 and submitted, at his request, to the National Security Council for review. The NSC is now looking at it. Hancock remarked that he had not yet seen this draft.

Nelson confirmed that Garfinckle (ISOO) put together this draft, which was the only one the NSC has before it. Hancock noted that the principal person responsible for the NSC review is George Bennett, Deputy National Security Adviser for Intelligence.
Hancock reemphasized Garfinckle’s direction to the committees to be imaginative and creative. The duration committee addressed the duration issue mainly as follows.

item.p: 1. Originating agency determination required (OADR). For example, should the new executive order abolish OADR as a classification device and instead have automatic declassification for certain kinds of information in certain categories? If there was an exception to automatic declassification, then specific reasons would have to be submitted to the NSC.

2. Exceptions such as technology, cryptology, and certain specified sources and methods would be identified, and target; dates, say 10, 15, or 20 years; would be set for systematic declassification review. Declassification would not be automatic. Review would occur at the end of this time, however, and such documents would no longer have to wait 30 or 50 years.
3. All documents not falling under 1 or 2 would be automatically declassified in three years.

div.p: In the ensuing discussion, Perkins asked who was to define the categories. Hancock responded that it would need to be at a senior level within the Department. Perkins also expressed concern about Garfinckle’s instructions to the task force, which had been discussed at the previous Committee meeting. He felt they encouraged the tightening of restrictions on documents rather than a spirit of openness, but Hancock disagreed.

Nelson and Kimball said these proposals sounded something like the Carter administration years when some documents could be automatically declassified after 10 years, but the officers had the classifiers put down the maximum time before required review. Perkins referred to the “stupid idea” of reclassifying already released documents during the Reagan years, and noted that the Hancock committee seemed to be going in the opposite direction. Hancock remarked that his committee interpreted its instructions to move in a “radical” way toward “more openness.” These were Garfinckle’s instructions to the committees, and that the same tone of instructions was stemming from the President and the NSC.

Kimball asked Hancock whether his committee had benefited from the experience of HO historians, HDR reviewers, and senior NARA declassification people, who have had hands-on experience in the field. Hancock replied affirmatively, noting that he and his staff as well as the committee had met with such representatives. The DS plan was progressing in two phases: discussing how information was presently safeguarded and whether the controls were sufficient, and 2) reexamining the memoranda of understanding (MOUs) between State and the other agencies on how to treat documents, especially Top Secret documents. He is presently preparing a draft response to the second issue. The problem is not the protection of State Department documents but of other agency documents. Kimball rejoined that his concern was not just MOUs or physical controls but historians’ experience in handling classified documents. Hancock said that the duration committee talked with Mr. Chaddic and others, and added that he was concerned not so much with physical security but information security, especially classification assignment. Nelson said that the path of the duration committee crossed with that of the declassification committee. Jean Schauble noted that Mike Kurtz chaired the declassification committee.

Hancock continued by saying that the Information Security Division in the State Department was focusing more on classification assignments rather than physical security controls. He believed that within the State Department, the great majority of documents should be unclassified. Guidance on classification is lacking in the Department, but his office has been studying the problem. He asked, for example, what should be classified? He has initiated a State Department task force to determine what subject areas are and are not sensitive. For example, can Limited Official Use (LOU) be used in the area of foreign economic policy? An action memorandum on a sensitive put unclassified program is currently being staffed.

Slany asked Hancock whether he could comment on reports in the newspapers that Congress would terminate ISOO at the end of this fiscal year. Hancock confirmed such proposals and that Senator Moynihan has proposed a secrecy commission to oversee all the task forces and committees looking at National Security issues. To a question from Perkins, Hancock commented that the money for the commission was proposed to come from the Department of State budget. He thought this would be a duplicative effort, and believed that at least the executive order should be issued first. We would have to see whether the Moynihan initiative is included in the appropriations bill.
Nelson thought that declassifiers did not seem to care whether documents were not declassified for 30-40 years. Hancock said the declassification committee might be addressing this question.

Kimball then asked, “How can the Historical Advisory Committee play a constructive role?” Hancock responded that the executive order was just a draft, and, in his opinion, the NSC will think the proposed changes are a healthy development. The NSC would be looking at it this week. ISOO had massaged it, and he hoped to see the NSC product very soon. Nelson noted that “the NSC” really meant a staff adviser at the NSC. She wanted to know whether the National Security Adviser was interested in the issue. Hancock stated that he was not aware if the National Security Adviser was involved in the issue but that a Mr. Podesta at the White House was interested in it. Nelson commented that the Advisory Committee should have some input if the draft was not classified.

Kimball suggested that Slany should stay in touch with Hancock so that the Committee would “not miss the train this time.” Hancock added that there will probably be several drafts of the executive order. Kimball continued that the Committee’s interest in the executive order as well as that of several professional, scholarly organizations should be made known to the drafters.

Page Miller commented that she has spent a lot of time on this issue, and she believed that the committee was developing more specific language and generally was moving in “much more helpful ways.” She preferred to wait to see a draft before HO moved on the question of vague definitions over what constitutes other agencies’ equities.
The Committee thanked Hancock as he left the meeting, and the committee adjourned shortly before noon to hold a brief closed session before lunch.

Bennett Freeman, Deputy Assistant Secretary, Bureau of Public Affairs, joined the Advisory Committee during its lunch. Freeman said that Donilon regretted that he was unable to attend the meeting or the luncheon. Mr. Freeman chatted with the Committee for about 20 minutes, during which time his comments were focused on the issue of PRD-29 and systematic declassification of the Department’s 30-year old records. He listened to the Committee’s concerns, which included a critique of the briefing it had heard from John Hancock of DS concerning the process by which ISOO is going about drafting a new presidential executive order on classification/ declassification. Mr. Freeman said that he would check on the status of the draft and explore the possibilities of how
the Department, and PA in particular, may play a bigger role in the creation of a new executive order. He also said that the declassification of 30-year old records was another priority concern of the Bureau, and he told the committee he would call a meeting with interested principals, to discuss congressional expectations and other matters concerning the Department’s efforts to meet the statutory deadlines. Mr. Freeman also assured the Committee that present vacancies, including two historians’ positions, would be filled as quickly as possible. He thanked the committee for all its good work.

Chairman Kimball called the session to order at 1:42 p.m. As a preliminary, he asked Chaddic to consult with NARA about adding information on withdrawal sheets so researchers can have more information about the documents.

Anne Van Camp began her report on the Van Camp-Nelson subcommittee by stating the goal of their trip to the Records Center at Suitland: to observe the process of the State historians’ access to DOD files. She explained the elaborate process: the historian has to decide which files he/she wants to see and then order them to be brought to the classified room.
She believed they needed two things to streamline the process:

item.p: 1) easier and better access to inventories/finding aids (Forms 135) -- possibly to have copies of these, and
2) being allowed to photocopy documents at Suitland.

div.p: The process now requires historians to fill out a form, have the whole box sent to the Pentagon where the specific documents are pulled and copies made. The process is very cumbersome. Making copies at Suitland would also protect the records better.

The DOD official who met with the subcommittee at Suitland, Brian Kinney, agreed that this was a problem and was warned that the Department would be asking for ways to streamline the process. He believed that no memorandum of understanding on access was necessary because State historians have access to DOD records, but he would draft one. He declined to meet with the Committee as a whole, but did meet with the subcommittee on DOD records.

Van Camp clarified the process for Kimball: DOD makes a list of the documents the State historian has requested, sends the list to originating agencies in order to alert the agencies that State historians are looking at their documents. Nelson said the major thing is to get a copying machine at Suitland. The main problem is the DOD procedure, which is laborious.
Schwar (who accompanied the subcommittee to Suitland) said that HO needs to have copies of the finding aids (135s). It is not a problem of access but of copying.

Langbart asked if HO has asked DOD to copy the 135s for particular accession numbers; the burden might as well be on DOD. Patterson and Schwar agreed. Patterson also pointed out that the State historians would still have to go to Suitland to identify accession numbers.

Kimball said that this problem should be solved in the memorandum of understanding with Defense. Schwar said that Kinney agreed that it would be helpful if State historians could copy documents at Suitland.
Langbart said the whole process came about because there were no copying facilities at Suitland, but Van Camp noted that Kinney said that it was because of accountability.
Kimball repeated that the memorandum of understanding should negotiate specific procedures and at a higher level than Brian Kinney.

Patterson asked about the document lists. Van Camp and Nelson said that the State historians cannot take the documents from Suitland, the documents must go to the Pentagon where the lists are made. Van Camp pointed out that if the documents don’t go back to the Pentagon, the State historians would have to make the lists. Van Camp ended her report by saying that everyone at Suitland was helpful and cooperative.
Kimball repeated that the memorandum of understanding will make the process less cumbersome for all.

Before moving to the next agenda item, Kimball wanted the minutes to show that Bennett Freeman at lunch had informed the Committee that the two historian vacancies in HO would be filled. He wanted to express the Committee’s appreciation for the support given to HO by the PA front office in personnel staffing in order to meet the statutory requirements.
Ken McDonald will now report on CIA publication and declassification activities.

McDonald began by saying that he had forwarded Kimball’s letter to the DCI with a draft response. Kimball’s letter had noted how important CIA records were to the Foreign Relations series and the need for CIA and PA/HO to continue to work together. If his draft was not changed, Kimball should be receiving a friendly response.
Kimball said McDonald and Slany would work out liaison for a long-term schedule for research in CIA records. Then he asked McDonald about CIA/HO liaison about the CIA publication program.
McDonald said the History Staff would be publishing several publications in conjunction with upcoming conferences:

item.p: -- newly declassified non-strategic Soviet estimates (15-20 from the 1950s) for a Symposium on Teaching Intelligence, 1-2 October.
-- strategic Soviet estimates -- already planned to accompany a conference scheduled for autumn 1994.

-- imagery and records from an early (1960s) overhead satellite reconnaissance system, which is about to be transferred to the National Air and Space Museum. These records will be declassified and some of them possibly published for a conference.

-- a book of documents on Truman and the origins of the CIA for a conference here co-sponsored by CIA and the Truman Library in March 1994. These documents should not duplicate those selected for the intelligence supplement prepared by Tom Thorne for the Foreign Relations series.

div.p: McDonald said that CIA does not want to compete with the Foreign Relations series, but the Center for the Study of Intelligence has planned an active schedule of conferences, and expects to publish a volume of newly declassified CIA records for each of these conferences.

Kimball thought it was important that the CIA not duplicate documents in the Foreign Relations series, but publish documents that have been previously withheld. McDonald agreed that this would require CIA/HO liaison.

Nelson pointed out that if the CIA wanted to prove it was really open, it should start answering FOIA requests. McDonald said that the responsibility for FOI is in the Directorate for
Administration, while the Center for the Study of Intelligence is in the Director’s office. The same declassification guidelines will soon be used throughout the CIA.

McDonald mentioned the list he had recently received from Slany and LaFantasie of State historians’ visits to the CIA. Mary McAuliffe had returned a list of CIA historians who would be their counterparts. The working relationship between the two offices is excellent.

McDonald then spoke of filling the gap in the published record, mentioning Iran 1953 and Guatemala 1954. On Guatemala, there are 272 archive boxes of materials ready for declassification, gathered for an early FOIA request. A CIA history of Guatemala has been written. He will discuss with Slany how to handle getting these documents published. On Iran, the CIA History Staff gave some 1953 material to Nina Noring before she retired. Material on Iran is very difficult to find in the Agency.

Kimball asked if the CIA history on Guatemala is classified. McDonald said yes, but he hopes it will eventually be declassified. The DCI is beginning to open up more subjects: Iran, Guatemala, the 1948 Italian elections.

In response to a question from Perkins, McDonald clarified that the History Staff arranges for access only; the John Pereira’s Historical Review Group (also in the Center for the Study of Intelligence) declassifies documents.
LaFantasie said that CIA should keep HO informed of topics that the DCI is recognizing. Kimball spoke of the need for regular briefing meetings. McDonald agreed to both.
Kimball asked McDonald to pass on to Pereira some declassification issues:

item.p: -- Names of CIA officials who are participating in policy meetings. The Committee was concerned that those names are arbitrarily excised.
-- Biographies of international officials. These will be appearing more often, especially in briefing books, and should be declassified.

-- Why do all NIEs have to go back to the CIA for declassification? Is there some way to declassify all NIEs before a certain date? McDonald said that the NIEs on the Soviet Union are being reviewed and released, but that there is no guarantee that the others would be as easy. There is no
decision to declassify all NIEs and SNIEs, which are classic finished intelligence that go to all policymakers. All references to sources and methods have already been purged. Kimball finally asked if it was necessary for State to refer to CIA State documents that provide input to NIEs.

-- Are CIA documents “pre-sanitized” before they leave the Agency in a routine attempt to remove sources and methods? McDonald said they are not, simply because it would be too difficult to have two versions of documents. Occasionally, however, some sensitive information is removed from classified documents before they circulate outside of CIA. He cited one example: in 1975 before CIA gave the Church Committee copies of several classified History Staff histories, CIA (with the Church Committee’s approval) deleted some names of sources. In any event, very little “raw reporting” leaves the Agency.
-- How do changes in the evolving CIA declassification policy get down to the working level at NARA and other agencies? For example code-words that are declassified.

div.p: McDonald said he would pass these concerns on to John Pereira.

McDonald said that CIA’s Historical Review Group is occupied until August 22 with reviewing JFK assassination materials, but that the Bay of Pigs, Iran, and Guatemala materials are at the top of the list for declassification review. Kimball said HO would be sending historians to CIA to look at the Iran records; McDonald agreed -- that would be useful.
Kimball thanked McDonald for coming to brief the Committee and for passing on its concerns to Pereira.

Arnold Taylor then reported on the Taylor/Nelson subcommittee evaluation of the manuscript of Foreign Relations, 1964-1968, Volume XI, on Arms Control. The goal of the subcommittee was to evaluate the new editorial policy to limit the number of documents printed and use editorial notes and footnotes to ensure the record is covered.

The subcommittee’s conclusion was that the completeness of the record was not harmed or compromised by the new policy, in fact the General Editor had added documents that the compilers had left out. The subcommittee was, however, concerned by the compilers’ reliance on the Glenn T. Seaborg journal, which has been published in a sanitized version in a few places, because the compilers had not been able to find some documents.

Although the subcommittee concluded that the new manuscript preparation guidelines did not “do damage” to the completeness of the record for this volume, it decided that this manuscript
was not a good test of the guidelines. Nelson felt this was not a good test because the issues are repetitive and arcane, so the omission of some documents may not be damaging. She believed that the subcommittee should look at a regional or bilateral volume.

Kimball wondered if the new manuscript functioned as a finding aid or guide to the files. LaFantasie pointed out that he hoped the editorial notes and footnotes would work as finding aids. Slany agreed that a bilateral volume might be a better test because it would involve many issues, some of which would have to be left out.
Perkins asked why the compilers could not find the documents.

Patterson explained that the arms control material for the Johnson period was very widespread, not like the 1950s where everything was in 2-3 lot files. The Seaborg Journal was used for records of meetings only when no other records of that meeting could be found.
Kimball asked Nelson and Taylor to look at a bilateral volume and asked LaFantasie to arrange the details with them.

Kimball asked LaFantasie and Slany if there were any declassification problems that they would like to bring before the Committee. They said they would have some at the next meeting. Kimball said he would like to hear at the next meeting about the Tibet documents, which by then the China desk officer would have had time to review.

Nelson wished to comment on the Action Plan for opening the Department’s 30-year old and older records. She believed that the plan was not as detailed or as precise as the Committee was led to believe at its last meeting. As written, the plan would do the same thing only faster; the process was not spelled out to make changes.

Kimball said that the understanding within the Working Group was that the plan would require a new attitude (Kimball quoted Chaddic as saying that he was “willing to accept a higher risk in the declassification process”). Some levels of review have also been eliminated.
Nelson said that the process of page-by-page review was still being used; she wants the Action Plan to spell out what’s going on.

Kimball noted the problem of agreeing on the definition of terms such as “bulk” declassification. The Action Plan cannot
Kimball noted the problem of agreeing on the definition of terms such as “bulk” declassification. The Action Plan cannot be too detailed, but a deadline has been agreed to, no matter what the process.

Nelson said she wants a more specific Action Plan and risk assessment procedure in order to speed declassification. She was troubled by Assistant Secretary Sherman’s letter that said the Working Group has made “bold, forward-looking recommendations.” Why is this not reflected in the Action Plan?

Kimball said that risk assessment must be preceded by a preliminary inventory, which, according to the Action Plan, will be completed by September 1. This will establish priorities to determine which records will be addressed first.
Nelson thought that the Action Plan the Committee looked at at its last meeting was a draft. Slany said that at that time, it was an internal Department of State document, which was later adopted.
Nelson said it was her understanding that the Committee had only tentatively approved the Working Group report; it had not “endorsed” it. Perkins also noted that Plan did not have a “drop-dead” date.

Kimball pointed out that the report has gone to the Hill. Nelson was uncomfortable that the Committee had signed off on something it will later regret. No attempt was made to add a minority view. The Committee will be held responsible for the Action Plan and this is going to be a “BIG problem.”
Kimball pointed out that the letter does not take away the Committee’s rights and responsibilities to monitor the implementation of the plan.

Van Camp added that the Committee did endorse the Plan at its last meeting and she did not understand Nelson’s concerns. The plan purports to achieve the goal of opening the records and the Committee still has the option to monitor and disagree.
Nelson thought that the Committee’s concerns and questions with the Plan should be made clear on paper and the Committee would carefully watch the implementation.
Kimball said that the drop-dead date was a major issue and the Working Group did not vote for one; it was probably a violation of the law.
Van Camp pointed out that Nelson should have expressed her minority views more explicitly at the last meeting.
Nelson said she wants her concerns to be on record. She will be cautious in the future to make sure that a paper is a draft or in final.
Kimball again asked Nelson to spell out her concerns.
Nelson repeated that the Working Group report does not change the procedure.
Kimball asked what changes she wanted; what should the Committee have done?
Nelson could only reply that she believed that the Committee should be independent from the Department of State and should maintain its commitments to its constituent societies.

There was a discussion of “bulk declassification” and the difficulty of defining it. Langbart provided the Archives definition: systematic survey of a collection; if nothing sensitive is found, then the collection is declassified; or files are identified that require page-by-page review.

Kimball said that Frank Machak was not enthusiastic about bulk declassification but has agreed and will give Chaddic a working definition. The Working Group had agreed not to supply definitions because it might prove difficult to clear within the Department. The Committee has to monitor the process.

Nelson felt the lack of definitions was a loophole. Van Camp believed that the Action Plan represented a major step forward and the Committee should give the plan a chance to work. The Action Plan is clear and the Department has promised to meet the deadlines it contains.
Kimball agreed that the Committee would monitor progress at its next meeting.
Chaddic reflected on how far this process has come from October 1992. Perkins was impressed at the pace of declassification: 12 people are currently declassifying 10, 000 pages per day.

Kimball delineated the priorities that Chaddic had set: the Central Files for March through December 1963 (to be completed by September 30, 1993); the Berlin Lot Files through the 1980s; and some Secretariat Lot Files (Cabinet meetings 1961-1963, Foreign Ministers Meetings 1940-1960, William Y. Elliott files). Chaddic will consult with the Committee about new priorities.

Kimball passed on an inquiry from Emily Rosenberg regarding interagency risk assessment teams. He believed that the issue was premature but the Committee will ask Chaddic for a report at its next meeting. The teams represent an important step and a major change in the procedures: declassification at the working level.
Kimball asked if INR records are protected under the CIA Act. No one knew.

Nelson asked about AID records. Chaddic responded that AID has its own declassification office and reviewers. Nelson assumed that AID is not affected by the 30-year rule; Kimball agreed. Patterson pointed out that AID has signed a memorandum of understanding regarding access.
Kimball asked if Roger Channel records were protected by the CIA Act. Chaddic pointed out that Roger Channel was limited distribution to State Department only.
Kimball wanted to express his appreciation for the fact that HDR received “earmarked” money for declassification. It was good to see the government put its money where its mouth was.

He then asked for old business. Schwar asked if INR had responded to the questions raised about its records at the last meeting. Kimball said yes but not very satisfactorily, and the Committee would take up the issue at its next meeting. INR understands in principle that HO needs access to its records.
Staff comments were requested. Patterson noted that DOD records were not subject to systematic review. Kimball and Slany noted that PRD-29 may address that issue.

LaFantasie said that the Navy is basing its systematic declassification review on State procedures. Langbart replied that Navy was only interested in Navy material and did not flag other agencies’ equities. When the material was sent to Archives it had to be re-reviewed, thereby making Navy’s review relatively useless.
The meeting adjourned at 3:50 p.m.

div.head: Memorandum for the Record
div.p: QUOTE: “As will be noted in the minutes of the August 5 meeting, I was somehwat dismayed to read the letter sent by Asst. Sec. Sherman to Chairmen Pell and Hamilton of the Senate and House Committees. In this letter, Sec. Sherman states that the Advisory Committee “endorsed” the recommendations of the State Department Working Group on reaching the 30 year declassification requirement. My chagrin was based on the erroneous assumption that we were discussing a draft of that document in our May meeting. I assumed we would see a final version. Hence I was also very critical of the enclosed Action Plan which I assumed to be the final report. I was told that I was the only one confused; that I should have raised questions or filed a dissenting opinion in May; that we had no need to receive the report sent to Congress because it was the one we had seen; and that the HAC did “endorse” the plan.

item.p: 1. The report we received in May was marked “revised draft.” Thus, there was every reason to believe we were discussing a draft and that before that draft was sent to Congress we would have a chance to comment on it in some way.

2. If, indeed, there was no intention to further change the report then the HAC wasted several hours discussing the draft. Although a representative of the HAC attended the working group meetings, the Committee as a whole had no input.

3. Reading the minutes of the meeting in May, one hardly gets the impression that the HAC “endorsed” the plan. In fact, the minutes do not indicate that a conclusion was reached. As I recall, we did agree that the working group should continue its efforts -- that is, we decided not to withdraw from participating in the task before the working group.

4. But the minutes reveal the misgivings of individual members of the HAC. There was general agreement that the State Department would not meet the 30 year deadline under this plan. Several members noted that (reflecting our organizations) we were committed to a “drop dead” date, but that this plan did not anticipate any such alternative. It was suggested that this plan mostly established the same process, only faster. Others noted that the risk assessment plan was the only really new recommendation. Questions were raised about the way the risk assessment plan would work. Although the HAC would be involved in helping with risk assessment, one member asked about the effect of the disagreement over risk by the HAC member. Would it be honored in any way? (There was no response).

5. The minutes also reveal that in this discussion, Kimball did note that the report was in its final form, but that the HAC could and “should” add its comments. However, in the press of business and perhaps because the Chair did not believe it useful, no comments were prepared. Quite frankly, I missed the significance of the fact that the report was in its final form given the heading of the Working Group report. Otherwise I would have either pressed for Committee comments or simply added my own.

6. Several times during the August 5 discussion, I was challenged to state the reasons for my concerns, given the fact that the HAC is supposed to monitor this plan. My basic concern is that in an effort to avoid confrontation (an effort I generally support) the Committee will lose its independence and compromise its function. We should not always go along in order to get along. We have to fulfill our obligations under the statute, represent our own organizations and preserve our own integrity. In this instance, our ability to question the efficacy of the Working Group plan has been seriously impaired because we are on record “endorsing” the plan without additional caveats that reflect our reservations.

7. There will no doubt be many instances in the future when individual members of the HAC will have to represent the Committee in meetings and private conversations. Each of us must feel free to state our own opinions but are obligated also to reflect the opinions of other Committee members. In this case, since the HAC did not want to discourage the positive aspects of the Working Group plan, additional comments from the HAC were in order to indicate various reservations and avoid the assumption of total ‘endorsement’." END QUOTE

div.p: Anna K. Nelson, Member Advisory Committee on Historical Diplomatic Documentation August 6, 1993
